Modification_Detail.description: Replaced mission LID urn:nasa:pds:context:investigation:individual.none with urn:nasa:pds:context:investigation:mission.venera_16. Added inst LID urn:nasa:pds:context:instrument:v16.ep. Added target LIDs urn:nasa:pds:context:target:planet.venus and urn:nasa:pds:context:target:plasma_stream.solar_wind. Added two external references. Deleted external reference to Cassini Mission Plan.
Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID
extracted metadata from PDS3 catalog and modified to comply with PDS4 Information Model EN snuck in changes that no one will care about.

External_Reference.reference_text: Huntress, W. T., and Marov, M. Ya., Soviet Robots in the Solar System, Springer-Praxis Books in Space Exploration, ISBN 978-1-4419-7898-1, Library of Congress Control Number 2011921306, 2011.

Instrument_Host.name: Venera 16
Instrument_Host.description: Venera 16 was launched alongside Venera 15 in 1983 and operated in tandem to map Venus’ surface. Like its counterpart, it was equipped with a radar system for surface imaging, focusing on the southern hemisphere of Venus. Venera 16 provided complementary radar data to help create a more comprehensive map of Venus’ surface features. The spacecraft also conducted atmospheric observations, contributing to the study of Venus' thick clouds and climate. Venera 16 transmitted valuable data back to Earth until 1984, further expanding knowledge about Venus' surface and atmosphere.
